baseline_groups.claim_summary: Adoption of national-standard medical liability rules leads to convergence of state health outcomes toward national averages, measured by absolute deviation of state Apgar scores from the national mean.
baseline_groups.sample_desc: State-year panel from vital statistics, 1977-2004, ~48 states
baseline_groups.controls_desc: fertility rate, hospital beds, OB/GYNs, tort reform variables (caps, collateral source, indirect liability), demographics (race, age, education)
baseline_groups.notes: Table 9 replication using vital statistics data. The positive coefficient indicates states move further from the national Apgar mean after adopting national-standard rules. This is the opposite direction from the paper's main cesarean convergence hypothesis (which uses restricted NHDS data not available in the replication package). The available vital statistics data replicates only the health outcome tables (Tables 9 and C-2), not the primary cesarean section analysis.

global_notes: Single baseline group. The paper's core finding about cesarean section convergence uses restricted NHDS data not available in the replication package. The specification search operates on the available vital statistics data, testing Apgar score convergence (Table 9) and related outcomes from Table C-2. The baseline result (p=0.028) is moderately significant but the positive sign suggests states diverge from national Apgar means after adoption -- contrary to the convergence hypothesis. The result is sensitive to fixed effects specification (disappears without state trends) and sample period (driven by full panel, not subperiods). The vital2 dataset provides additional Table C-2 specifications with different outcome variables (logapgar5, good2, log_nn28) and treatment (ln_stand_cs).
